items.title: Update index.md

items.content_html:
This is a follow-up to #29023. I fully expect this PR to be rejected. I'm surprised that Prettier didn't reformat it. I was surprised to see the tabular formatting in CSS on this page. But it is easier to read, isn't it?

What can I say? After years of programming for accountants and financial analysts I grew accustomed tabular formatting, especially when it comes to numbers. I don't expect others here to share my enthusiasm, but this page opened the door. This PR seeks to clarify how wide that door is open.
items.title: CSS cross-fade examples fully tab-aligned

items.content_html:
The tiniest of changes in the 2nd CSS example. It aligns the final example's url() with the others. All the others above it are already aligned. Best viewed in the preview.

You might well decide that Prettier should reformat all the CSS examples and remove this tabular alignment instead.
items.title: CSS cross-fade tabular alignment tweak

items.content_html:
For long the slice has been a source of confusion among developers. Apart from it's similarity with the splice in terms of name , I feel the naming of the parameters has also contributed. Also I had to specify what happens when we have negative arguments because clearly what happens with single negative arguments is different from what happens generally with the slice. Also naming our second parameter indexEnd is confusing because that particular index is not a part of it , as long as we counting from 0.

Description

Had to change parameter names and threw more light on negative indexes.

Motivation

The slice has been a source of confusion for so long and I think the parameter names and negative indexes contributed.

Additional details

Related issues and pull requests
items.title: Update index.md  indexEnd is not the end since we actually end before it

Additional details

items.content_html:
• fixes #29005

It is helpful to document the required parameters first then the optional parameters. For usage in code no guideline exist about the order. Also Prettier has no opinion about this. We can show all allowed combinations of values in the "Syntax" section.

The PR does following changes:

  • updates the syntax section to cover various scenarios
  • uses {{optional_inline}} badge. All non optional params are mandatory.
  • adds playable example
  • use standard-deviation instead of blur-radius. The drop-shadow and box-shadow implementations use different algorithms.
items.title: fix(css): update 'drop-shadow()' page

items.content_html:
Description

As part of my see-also checker work, I have found a way to parse macros so I can check for consistent macro text. In this process I found it better to make all macros uniform. This PR makes macro text conform to Prettier style as well, and uses consistent casing for all macros.

Motivation

items.title: Use consistent formatting for all macros

items.content_html:
This updates RTCRtpTransceiver.currentDirection and RTCRtpTransceiver.direction and friends to note that the way to determine whether a transceiver is stopped is to check these values against the stopped string.

It also spells what these directions actually mean - ie what is a direction, and why you need a preferred vs a current.

... and brings the docs that have been touched in line with current templates.

Related docs work can be tracked in #28845
items.title: FF118 RTCRtpTransceiver directions include stopped option

items.content_html:
Description

Fixed the reversed logic on Using the imscJS polyfill code sample

i < timeEvents.length - 1 === true means it's not the last time event so the new Cue's end time should be the next time event.

Motivation

The original example code was wrong and caused confusion
items.title: fix reversed code logic on Using the imscJS polyfill page

items.content_html:
Description

Smoothly animate seconds hand in the clock in the Animated Clock example for canvas. Sample video below:

Screen.Recording.2023-09-08.at.5.39.29.AM.mp4

Motivation

To properly showcase the fact that the canvas is drawn 60 times per second, the second hand in the clock now smoothly moves instead of jumping from tick to tick (once per second).

Additional details

  • Applies to: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Canvas_API/Tutorial/Basic_animations#an_animated_clock
  • Tested using MDN Playground.

Related issues and pull requests

None

PS: Please use "Squash and Merge"; thank you.
items.title: Smoothly animate seconds hand in the clock

items.content_html:
We don't mention subgrid or nesting grids in the learn doc, this PR adds some more examples and links to subgrid where possible.

additions:

  • nested grid example
  • example using subgrid
  • link to subgrid in See Also

changes:

  • Height of embedded examples to make vertical space a little tighter
  • Some flyby tidy up

follow-ups:
It might be nice to add the example with nested grids to be available to download in the learning area. Pending review changes on that.
items.title: docs(css): Add details about subgrid to Grid Learn article

items.content_html:
Description

Enhancing the example in the documentation for seekforward and seekbackward events when using Media Session API The changes include the explicit introduction of the seekOffset property within the event object passed to the respective event callback functions. These modifications offer developers a clearer understanding of the seekOffset property, providing crucial information about the user's seek actions. Additionally, the updated example acknowledges that if the seekOffset property is absent in the event, developers can gracefully default to a predefined seek value, typically 10 seconds.

Motivation

When setting an action handler for the seekforward or seekbackward events, the main piece of information the developers are looking for is how many seconds the user seeks forward or backwards, essentially, the number of seconds to seek. If this information is not readily available, developers can fall back to a fixed seek value, such as 10 seconds.

However, I encountered an issue when referencing the example provided in the documentation. The example consistently used a fixed 10-second seek time and did not utilize the seekOffset property at all. This omission caused confusion for me, as it was not clear how to obtain the essential seekOffset information when listening to these events.
items.title: Clarify Media Session API Example: Highlight the Use of `seekOffset` Property in `seekforward` and `seekbackward` Events
